qas.question: What Psalm gives the words of Jesus on the cross?
What contradiction is found in this Psalm?

answers.text: verse is cited in Aramaic rather than the Hebrew

qas.question: What was the psalm said to be in Jesus' time?

answers.text: a proverbial saying in common usage

qas.question: How do the other gospels describe Jesus' last words?
How does the sentence appear to historians?
What kind of writing did Geza Vermes usually produce?
What language did Geza Vermes study while in school?
What language was learned by Geza Vermes when he was a child?
How did Raymond Brown describe the effect Jesus had on society?
Does Geza Vermes believe that there is a valid argument against the existence of Jesus?

context: The only words of Jesus on the cross in the Mark and Matthew accounts, this is a quotation of <a0_0>Psalm 22<a0_0/>. Since other verses of the same Psalm are cited in the crucifixion accounts, it is often considered a <b5_0>literary and theological<b5_0/> creation. Geza Vermes, however, points out that the <a1_0>verse is cited in <b6_0>Aramaic<b6_0/> rather than the <b7_0>Hebrew<b7_0/><a1_0/> in which it usually would have been recited, and suggests that by the time of Jesus, this phrase had become <a2_0>a proverbial saying in common usage<a2_0/>. Compared to the accounts in the other Gospels, which he describes as '<a3_0>theologically correct and reassuring<a3_0/>', he considers this phrase '<b8_0>unexpected, disquieting<b8_0/> and in consequence more probable'. He describes it as bearing 'all the appearances of <a4_0>a genuine cry<a4_0/>'. Raymond Brown likewise comments that he finds '<b9_0>no persuasive argument<b9_0/> against attributing to the Jesus of Mark/Matt the literal sentiment of feeling forsaken expressed in the Psalm quote'.
